desc: Body Mass Index (BMI) is a simple tool used to assess whether a person is within a healthy weight range. By using a BMI calculator, you can quickly determine your BMI value, which helps evaluate your weight status.  This index is widely used to screen for underweight, normal weight, overweight, or obesity.

indexAnalysis.Underweight: There may be insufficient body fat and muscle mass. This can be accompanied by a weakened immune system (prone to colds and infections), anemia, menstrual irregularities (in women), and an increased risk of osteoporosis. Some people may have a low body weight due to poor nutrient absorption or a high basal metabolism.
indexAnalysis.Normal: The body weight matches the height well, with a harmonious proportion of overall fat and muscle. The risk of metabolic diseases (such as diabetes, hypertension) and cardiovascular diseases is relatively low. This represents an ideal state of health.
indexAnalysis.Overweight: The body fat content is relatively high, especially abdominal fat. Although it doesn't reach the level of obesity, it has already started to increase the risk of metabolic abnormalities. There may be a slight increase in blood lipids and a decrease in insulin sensitivity. The risk of hypertension and fatty liver is significantly higher compared to the normal population.
indexAnalysis.Obesity: There is a large accumulation of body fat, especially visceral fat, which is a high - risk factor for metabolic syndrome (hypertension, hyperglycemia, hyperlipidemia, abdominal obesity). It significantly increases the risk of type 2 diabetes, coronary heart disease, stroke, sleep apnea syndrome, joint wear (such as knee joints), and some cancers (such as breast cancer, liver cancer). Urgent intervention is needed.

exerciseSuggestions.Underweight: Focus on muscle gain. Reduce aerobic exercises that consume a large amount of calories. Do light  intensity aerobic exercise only 1 - 2 times a week.- Emphasize resistance training (strength training). Do it 3 - 4 times a week, targeting large muscle groups (chest, back, glutes and legs), such as dumbbell bench press, pull - ups, barbell squats. Each session lasts 30 - 40 minutes to increase body weight through muscle growth. Ensure sufficient rest after training (muscles repair and grow during rest) and avoid over - training.
exerciseSuggestions.Normal: Maintain regular exercise. Do at least 150 minutes of moderate - intensity aerobic exercise per week (such as jogging, swimming, cycling), or 75 minutes of high - intensity aerobic exercise (such as skipping rope, interval running).Do resistance training 2 - 3 times a week (such as squats, deadlifts, planks) to maintain muscle mass and basal metabolism, and prevent muscle loss with age.Add flexibility training to improve joint flexibility and reduce the risk of sports injuries.
exerciseSuggestions.Overweight: Aiming at fat loss, increase the duration of aerobic exercise: Do 150 - 250 minutes of moderate - intensity aerobic exercise per week (such as brisk walking, jogging, using an elliptical machine), or 75 - 125 minutes of high - intensity interval training (HIIT) to boost fat - burning efficiency.Do resistance training 3 times a week (targeting the whole - body muscle groups), like dumbbell curls, hip bridges, push - ups, to maintain muscle mass (prevent muscle loss during fat loss).Reduce sedentary time. Increase daily activities every day (such as taking the stairs, walking to and from work), with a cumulative 8,000 - 10,000 steps.
exerciseSuggestions.Obesity: Follow the principle of gradual progress to avoid high - intensity exercise from increasing the burden on joints or the cardiovascular system, especially for those with severe obesity.In the initial stage, start with low - intensity aerobic exercise (such as brisk walking, swimming, cycling), 5 - 6 times a week, 20 - 30 minutes each time, and gradually extend it to 40 - 60 minutes.For resistance training, focus on light weights and multiple repetitions. Do it 3 times a week to improve muscle function and boost metabolism.Avoid actions that involve bending over or bearing excessive weight to protect the knee joints and lumbar spine.It is essential to warm up thoroughly (5 - 10 minutes) and stretch (5 - 10 minutes) before and after exercise to reduce the risk of injury.

DietaryAdvice.Underweight: Increase calorie intake by choosing nutrient - dense foods instead of junk food.Raise the proportion of high - quality protein, such as eggs, milk, lean meat, fish, shrimp, and protein powder, to promote muscle synthesis.Moderately increase healthy fats and complex carbohydrates (like whole - wheat bread, brown rice, sweet potatoes) to ensure an adequate calorie supply.If being underweight is due to poor absorption, you can take probiotics or consult a doctor to improve digestive function.
DietaryAdvice.Normal: Maintain a balanced diet and control total calories. Carbohydrates should account for 50% - 60% of daily intake, protein 15% - 20%, and fat (mainly unsaturated fat) 20% - 30%.Consume 300 - 500g of vegetables and 200 - 350g of fruits daily to ensure dietary fiber and vitamins.Reduce processed foods (such as sausages, potato chips) and added sugars (sweet beverages, pastries). Keep the diet light (salt intake ≤ 5g per day).Eat regularly, avoid overeating, and don't over - eat at dinner, especially within 3 hours before bedtime.
DietaryAdvice.Overweight: Control total calories and lose fat slowly through a calorie deficit (it's advisable to lose 0.5 - 1kg per week).Reduce refined carbohydrates and replace them with low - GI foods. The amount of staple food per meal should be about the size of one fist.Increase protein intake (1.2 - 1.5g per kg of body weight per day), such as chicken breast, fish, shrimp, and tofu, to enhance satiety and reduce muscle loss.Eat more vegetables (about two fists per meal) to increase dietary fiber and slow down the rise of blood sugar.Reduce high - oil and high - sugar foods. Use steaming, boiling, and baking for cooking, and avoid braising and frying.
DietaryAdvice.Obesity: Strictly control calories while ensuring basic nutrition. It is recommended to develop a plan under the guidance of a nutritionist.Choose whole grains and legumes as the main sources of carbohydrates, and strictly avoid refined sugars.Increase the proportion of protein to 25% - 30% to enhance satiety and reduce muscle loss.Mainly consume unsaturated fats, with daily intake ≤ 20% of total calories. Avoid animal fats and trans - fats.Drink 2000 - 2500 ml of water per day to promote metabolism and satiety. Eat regularly and avoid late - night snacks.For those with severe obesity, it is advisable to combine medical evaluation. If necessary, carry out drug or surgical intervention under the guidance of a doctor.

desc: ABSI (A Body Shape Index) is a metric designed to assess abdominal fat distribution, addressing the limitations of traditional BMI (Body Mass Index). While BMI considers only height and weight, it doesn’t account for how fat is distributed throughout the body, particularly around the abdomen. Excess abdominal fat is closely linked to various health risks, including cardiovascular diseases and diabetes. ABSI provides a more comprehensive perspective for evaluating health risks.

indexAnalysis.Very Low: Your body shape index is significantly below average, with low health risks.Your body type and metabolic state are relatively healthy. It is recommended to focus on maintaining the current situation and preventing risks.
indexAnalysis.Low Risk: Your body shape index is slightly below average, with minimal health risks.It is necessary to avoid the accumulation of bad habits to prevent the development towards a high - risk state.
indexAnalysis.Average: Your body shape index is close to average, with typical health risks.You need to take the initiative to adjust your lifestyle to reduce abdominal fat and metabolic burden.
indexAnalysis.High Risk: Your body shape index is above average, suggesting increased health risks.There is a certain risk of metabolic abnormalities (such as insulin resistance, dyslipidemia), so intensive intervention is needed to reduce abdominal and visceral fat.
indexAnalysis.Very High: Your body shape index is significantly above average, indicating high risks.You belong to the high - risk group for metabolic diseases (such as a significantly increased risk of diabetes and cardiovascular diseases). It is recommended to develop a personalized plan under the guidance of a doctor or a nutritionist, combined with lifestyle adjustments.

exerciseSuggestions.Very Low: Maintain 150 - 300 minutes of moderate - intensity aerobic exercise (such as brisk walking, jogging, swimming) per week, or 75 - 150 minutes of high - intensity aerobic exercise (such as skipping rope, sprinting).Increase daily activity levels, such as taking the stairs, commuting by bike, etc., and keep the daily step count between 6000 - 10000 steps.
exerciseSuggestions.Low Risk: Engage in at least 150 minutes of moderate - intensity aerobic exercise per week. It can be split into 30 minutes per day for 5 days (such as brisk walking, cycling). Avoid not exercising for 3 consecutive days.Reduce sitting time. Get up and move around for 5 minutes every hour (such as stretching, taking a walk).
exerciseSuggestions.Average: Do 200 - 300 minutes of moderate - intensity aerobic exercise per week. You can add interval training (for example, jog for 1 minute + walk briskly for 2 minutes, repeat 10 sets) to improve the fat - burning efficiency.Carry out resistance training 3 times a week, covering the whole body muscle groups (chest, back, legs, core), 30 - 45 minutes each time (such as squats, push - ups, rows).Do 10 - minute targeted abdominal training every day (such as Russian twists, hip bridges) to improve the abdominal lines.
exerciseSuggestions.High Risk: Do at least 250 minutes of aerobic exercise per week, mainly of moderate - low intensity (such as brisk walking, swimming, using an elliptical machine) to avoid over - burdening joints from strenuous exercise.Conduct resistance training 3 - 4 times a week, starting with light weights and multiple sets (for example, dumbbell curls 15 times × 3 sets), gradually increasing muscle mass to improve metabolism.Add 10 - 15 minutes of abdominal breathing + core tightening training every day (for example, lie flat, inhale to expand the abdomen, exhale to contract the abdomen, repeat 20 times) to enhance abdominal control.
exerciseSuggestions.Very High: In the initial stage, mainly do low - intensity aerobic exercise, 20 - 30 minutes each time, 5 - 6 times a week, and gradually increase to moderate intensity (control the heart rate at 60% - 70% of the maximum heart rate, and the maximum heart rate = 220 - age).Start resistance training with bodyweight training (such as wall sits, seated leg raises), 2 - 3 times a week, 20 minutes each time, to avoid excessive joint pressure.Do 5 - 10 minutes of full - body stretching every day to improve blood circulation and reduce the risk of sports injuries.

DietaryAdvice.Very Low: Maintain a balanced diet. Consume an adequate amount of vegetables (300 - 500g), fruits (200 - 350g), whole grains (such as oats, brown rice, accounting for more than one - third of staple foods) and high - quality protein (fish, poultry, eggs, beans) every day.
DietaryAdvice.Low Risk: Reduce the proportion of refined carbohydrates (white rice, white bread), replace part of the staple food with miscellaneous beans and tubers, and control the daily intake of staple food.ive priority to unsaturated fats (such as olive oil, nuts, deep - sea fish), reduce the intake of animal fats (such as lard, butter), and keep the daily cooking oil intake within 25g.Increase the intake of dietary fiber (such as eating celery and apples with the skin). Have at least 25g of dietary fiber per day to help maintain satiety and intestinal health.
DietaryAdvice.Average: Strictly control foods high in sugar, salt and fat (such as hot pot, barbecue, sweet drinks), no more than 1 - 2 times a week, and halve the intake each time.Increase the proportion of protein (15% - 20% of daily calories), for example, add 1 egg to breakfast and 100g of chicken breast to lunch, to help maintain muscles and reduce hunger.For dinner, mainly have vegetables and high - quality protein (such as vegetable salad + steamed fish), control the staple food intake to 50 - 100g, and do not eat 3 hours before going to bed.
DietaryAdvice.High Risk: Adopt a low - GI (glycemic index) diet, avoid refined sugar and high - GI foods (white congee, cakes, watermelons), and choose foods with a GI < 55 (such as oats, quinoa, strawberries).Limit the total daily calorie intake (reduce 300 - 500 calories compared to daily needs), but not below the basal metabolic rate   to avoid excessive dieting.Keep the daily salt intake below 5g, reduce processed foods (such as sausages, canned foods), and use spices (ginger, garlic, black pepper) to replace some of the salt when cooking.
DietaryAdvice.Very High: Strictly follow the principle of controlling sugar, oil and total amount. Give priority to natural foods (such as fresh vegetables, lean meat, unsweetened yogurt), and avoid any processed snacks and sweet drinks.Adopt the eating small meals frequently mode (5 - 6 meals a day, 3 main meals + 2 - 3 snacks). For snacks, you can choose a small handful of nuts (10g) or one hard - boiled egg to avoid blood sugar fluctuations caused by an empty stomach.Increase the intake of omega - 3 fatty acids (for example, eat deep - sea fish 2 - 3 times a week, such as salmon, sardines) to help improve blood lipid and inflammatory response.

desc: Waist-to-Hip Ratio  is a key indicator used to assess how fat is distributed in the body. It’s calculated by comparing the circumference of your waist to that of your hips, giving insights into where fat accumulates, especially around the abdomen. It can more accurately reflect the amount of abdominal visceral fat (excessive abdominal fat is more harmful to health), and is better than body weight or BMI in predicting the risks of metabolic and cardiovascular diseases.

indexAnalysis.Normal: With a low level of abdominal fat, especially visceral fat, the metabolic function remains stable. This leads to a lower risk of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, type 2 diabetes, and cardiovascular diseases, indicating a generally good state of health.
indexAnalysis.Moderate Risk: Abdominal fat is starting to accumulate, and the content of visceral fat is increasing. There may be a decrease in insulin sensitivity and dyslipidemia (elevated triglycerides and decreased high - density lipoprotein). The risk of metabolic syndrome and cardiovascular diseases has increased significantly compared to the normal range, but it has not yet reached a high - risk level.
indexAnalysis.High Risk: Abdominal obesity is obvious, with a large accumulation of visceral fat. This is a typical manifestation of metabolic syndrome (co - existing hypertension, hyperglycemia, hyperlipidemia, and abdominal obesity), which significantly increases the risk of type 2 diabetes, coronary heart disease, stroke, fatty liver, and certain cancers (such as colorectal cancer and breast cancer). High vigilance is required.

exerciseSuggestions.Normal: Just maintain regular exercise. Do at least 150 minutes of moderate - intensity aerobic exercise per week (such as brisk walking, jogging, swimming, cycling);Do strength training 2 - 3 times a week (targeting the whole body muscle groups, like squats, deadlifts, push - ups) to maintain muscle mass and basal metabolism;You can appropriately add flexibility training (yoga, Pilates) to improve body flexibility.
exerciseSuggestions.Moderate Risk: Increase the intensity and duration of aerobic exercise: Do 200 - 300 minutes of moderate - intensity aerobic exercise per week (such as jogging, skipping rope, using an elliptical machine), or 100 - 150 minutes of high - intensity interval training (HIIT, like alternating between sprinting and slow walking) to boost fat - burning efficiency.Strengthen core training: Focus on reducing abdominal fat. Do 3 - 4 abdominal - targeted workouts per week (plank, crunch, Russian twist, side plank), 20 - 30 minutes each time.Enhance whole - body resistance training: Do it 3 times a week (with a 48 - hour interval), targeting large muscle groups (glutes and legs, back, chest), such as weighted squats, lunges, and pull - ups, to increase muscle mass and thus raise the basal metabolism.
exerciseSuggestions.High Risk: Follow the principle of progress step by step and safety first to avoid injuries caused by high - intensity exercise.In the initial stage, start with low - intensity aerobic exercise, 5 times a week, 30 - 40 minutes each time, and gradually increase to moderate intensity.Core training should be gentle. Avoid movements that increase abdominal pressure like crunches. Do it 3 times a week, 15 - 20 minutes each time.For whole - body resistance training, focus on light weights and multiple repetitions (such as resistance band training, bodyweight squats), 3 times a week, to improve muscle function.Warm up thoroughly (5 - 10 minutes) and stretch (5 - 10 minutes) before and after exercise to avoid joint injuries.

DietaryAdvice.Normal: Maintain a balanced diet and control total calorie intake (to avoid excessive intake leading to fat accumulation).Ensure sufficient daily intake of vegetables (300 - 500g), fruits (200 - 350g), and whole grains (such as oats, brown rice).Consume an appropriate amount of high - quality protein (fish, poultry, eggs, soy products, low - fat milk), and reduce processed meats (sausages, bacon).
DietaryAdvice.Moderate Risk: Control total calories (reduce 300 - 500 calories per day compared to daily requirements), but avoid excessive dieting (to prevent a decrease in metabolism).Reduce refined carbohydrates (white rice, white bread, noodles) and replace them with low - GI foods (quinoa, buckwheat, corn).Increase dietary fiber intake (vegetables, mushrooms, algae) to slow down blood sugar rise and enhance satiety.Increase the proportion of high - quality protein (accounting for 20% - 30% of daily calories), such as salmon, chicken breast, eggs, tofu, and reduce the frequency of red meat (pork, beef, mutton) intake.Strictly limit high - sugar foods (milk tea, candies) and alcohol (especially beer, which easily leads to a beer belly). Use steaming, boiling, and baking for cooking, and avoid frying.
DietaryAdvice.High Risk: Strictly control calorie intake while ensuring basic nutrition. It is recommended to develop a plan under the guidance of a nutritionist.Choose whole grains and miscellaneous beans as the main source of carbohydrates, and avoid any refined sugar.Increase the proportion of high - quality protein to 30% - 40% to promote muscle repair and delay hunger.Mainly consume unsaturated fats, strictly limit saturated and trans - fats, and keep daily fat intake ≤ 25% of the total calories.Drink 2000 - 2500ml of water per day to boost metabolism. Eat regularly and avoid overeating or having late - night snacks.If necessary, consult a doctor or nutritionist to check for underlying problems such as insulin resistance and thyroid dysfunction, and adjust the diet accordingly.

desc: Ideal weight refers to the most suitable body weight for a person under the premise of health. It is an important indicator to measure whether a person is in a healthy state. Being underweight or overweight may have an adverse impact on health.Generally speaking, if the actual weight is within ±10% of the ideal weight, it is considered normal. If it exceeds the ideal weight by 10% - 20%, it is overweight; if it exceeds by more than 20%, it is obese. If it is 10% - 20% lower than the ideal weight, it is regarded as thin; if it is lower by more than 20%, it is severely thin.

Target heart rate refers to a heart rate range set during exercise of a certain intensity to achieve optimal training effects. Staying within this heart rate range allows you to enhance your workout effectiveness without placing excessive strain on your heart.

The Navy Body Fat Percentage is a method used to estimate body fat by measuring specific body circumferences. Compared to other body fat measurement techniques like skinfold calipers or complex body composition analyzers, the Navy Body Fat Calculator is much simpler. It requires only the measurement of waist, neck, and hip circumference (for women) along with height to provide an estimated body fat percentage using a specific formula.This method was initially developed by the U.S. Navy to assess the health and fitness levels of service members. Because it's easy to use and requires minimal equipment, the Navy Body Fat Calculator has become one of the most widely used methods for estimating body fat. It’s particularly helpful for those who want to quickly assess their body fat without needing complex equipment.

indexAnalysis.Low: Your Navy Body Fat percentage is below the healthy lower limit. It may be accompanied by overly distinct muscle lines, lack of energy, and poor cold tolerance.
indexAnalysis.Normal: Your Navy Body Fat percentage is within the normal range and your physical fitness can meet the needs of daily training. However, if you don't pay attention to your diet and exercise, your body fat may gradually exceed the standard.
indexAnalysis.High: Your body fat is on the high side. You may experience a decline in physical fitness, such as being unable to complete standard weighted training or failing the endurance test. Moreover, you may have early - stage health problems like fatty liver and high blood lipid.
indexAnalysis.Very High: Your body fat is excessively high. You may have obesity - related diseases (such as hypertension, diabetes). Your physical fitness is severely insufficient, and you're prone to fatigue or injury during exercise. Intervention under the guidance of medical staff and fitness coaches is needed.

exerciseSuggestions.Low: Reduce high - intensity aerobic training: Limit the number of aerobic exercises to 1 - 2 times a week, mainly with low - intensity ones (such as brisk walking, jogging), 20 - 30 minutes each time, to avoid excessive calorie consumption.Ensure sufficient rest: Sleep 7 - 9 hours a day. Muscles repair and grow during rest. Avoid over - training which may exacerbate energy consumption.
exerciseSuggestions.Normal: Maintain regular exercise. Do strength training 3 - 4 times a week (targeting the whole - body muscle groups, such as squats, deadlifts, pull - ups), 40 - 60 minutes each time.Do aerobic training 2 - 3 times a week (running, swimming, using a rowing machine), 30 - 45 minutes each time, at a moderate intensity (heart rate at 60% - 70% of the maximum heart rate).Include 1 - 2 flexibility training sessions to prevent sports injuries.
exerciseSuggestions.High: Focus on moderate - low intensity aerobic training, 5 times a week, 45 - 60 minutes each time (such as brisk walking, swimming, using an elliptical machine) to avoid joint injuries.Do light - weight strength training 2 - 3 times a week (such as dumbbell bench press, bodyweight squats), 12 - 15 repetitions per set, to increase muscle mass and metabolism.Accumulate 8000 - 10000 steps of walking daily, and gradually increase the exercise duration and intensity (for example, increase the exercise volume by 5% every week).
exerciseSuggestions.Very High: In the initial stage, mainly do extremely low - intensity exercises (such as walking, water walking), 3 - 4 times a week, 20 - 30 minutes each time to avoid excessive joint pressure.Gradually transition to moderate - low intensity aerobic exercises (such as slow cycling), increasing the duration by 5 - 10 minutes per week until it reaches 45 minutes each time.For strength training, focus on bodyweight movements (such as wall sits, seated leg raises), 8 - 10 repetitions per set, with an emphasis on protecting the knees and lower back. Warm - up and stretch thoroughly before and after exercise to avoid injuries. It is recommended to conduct a physical function assessment (such as heart rate and blood pressure monitoring) once a week.

DietaryAdvice.Low: Moderately increase calorie intake: Increase 300 - 500 calories per day, mainly from high - quality carbohydrates and healthy fats.Increase the proportion of carbohydrates: Choose whole grains. Daily intake can be increased to 5 - 7g/kg of body weight. Supplement promptly after exercise to promote glycogen storage.Increase the intake of healthy fats: Raise the daily fat intake to 1 - 1.2g/kg of body weight. Give priority to avocados, nuts, olive oil, and deep - sea fish. Avoid fried foods.Ensure the basic protein intake: Maintain 1.2 - 1.4g/kg of body weight and choose easily - digestible sources.Eat small meals frequently: Avoid overeating at one time which may cause gastrointestinal discomfort. You can add a serving of nuts, fruits, or energy bars between meals.
DietaryAdvice.Normal: Maintain a balanced diet with a reasonable ratio of protein (1.2 - 1.6g/kg of body weight), carbohydrates (4 - 6g/kg of body weight), and healthy fats (0.8 - 1g/kg of body weight).Consume more whole grains, lean meats (chicken breast, fish, shrimp), eggs, low - fat dairy products, and fresh fruits and vegetables. Control processed foods and high - sugar snacks.Ensure sufficient water intake (2 - 3L per day) and avoid excessive alcohol consumption.
DietaryAdvice.High: Strictly control calorie intake (reduce 500 - 800 calories per day), and adopt a low - GI diet (choose low - glycemic - index foods like brown rice, quinoa, and beans).Greatly reduce foods high in sugar, oil, and salt (such as hot pot, barbecue, pickled products), and avoid sugary drinks.Have a daily protein intake of 1.6 - 2.0g/kg of body weight (such as protein powder, chicken breast), and control carbohydrate intake at 3 - 4g/kg of body weight, preferably consumed before and after exercise.
DietaryAdvice.Very High: Develop a personalized diet plan under the guidance of a nutritionist. Strictly control the total calories (reduce 800 - 1000 calories per day), but ensure sufficient basic nutrition (protein, vitamins, minerals).Almost eliminate refined carbohydrates and added sugars. Replace staple foods with whole grains and legumes, and keep the daily carbohydrate intake no more than 2 - 3g/kg of body weight.Increase the intake of dietary fiber (such as konjac, leafy greens) and water to avoid overeating caused by hunger.Eat small and frequent meals (5 - 6 meals a day, with a 3 - hour interval between each meal) to avoid long periods of fasting.
